translations:
proof (prove)
goal (1 subgoal):
 1. QCOERCE[L] (\<^bold>c \<^bold>\<cdot> julian_year) \<cong>\<^sub>Q
    \<^bold>c \<^bold>\<cdot> julian_year

proof (prove)
using this:
  light_year \<cong>\<^sub>Q \<^bold>c \<^bold>\<cdot> julian_year
  (?x \<cong>\<^sub>Q ?y) =
  (\<lbrakk>?x\<rbrakk>\<^sub>Q = \<lbrakk>?y\<rbrakk>\<^sub>Q \<and>
   QD(?'u\<^sub>1) = QD(?'u\<^sub>2))

goal (1 subgoal):
 1. \<lbrakk>light_year\<rbrakk>\<^sub>Q =
    \<lbrakk>\<^bold>c \<^bold>\<cdot> julian_year\<rbrakk>\<^sub>Q
text \<open> HOL can characterise \<^const>\<open>pi\<close> exactly and so we also give an exact value for the parsec. \<close>

text \<open> We calculate some conservative bounds on the parsec: it is somewhere between 3.26 and 3.27
  light-years. \<close>

text\<open> The full beauty of the approach is perhaps revealed here, with the 
      type of a classical three-dimensional gravitation field:\<close>
